BB_1938_title_recto: Group of warriors discussing and running towards tent

BB_1961_title_recto: Taccuino di Giuliano da San Gallo formato da 51 fogli, tolti a quaderni diversi, con date che vanno dal 23 Maggio 1500 al 24 Luglio 1513 Sono in massima parte studi architettonici, macchine belliche, ornati, grottesche e copie da antichi monumenti romani
BB_1961_text_recto: Per il nostro scopo i pi√π interessanti sono: fol. 1 - Aquila. fol. 11 - Tre fregi sovrapposti: un attacco di cavalieri; trionfo di un generaleromano; uomini, putti e centauri. Evidentemente ispirati, se non copiati, da bassorilievi romani. fol. 22 verso e fol. 23 recto - In alto, lungo fregio (su due pagine) con battaglia di cavalieri nudi; in basso visione frontale e laterale dell'arco di Orange. fol. 24 - L'Arco di Costantino a Roma e quattro medaglioni in rilievo. fol. 24 verso e fol. 25 recto - L'Arco di Traiano a Benevento e quattro processioni di figure toga te (su due pagine). fol. 28 - Tre fregi: re barbari catturati da duci romani; satiri e centauri. fol. 29 verso - Corteo dionisiaco; soldati romani che guadano un fiume. fol. 32 - Giuditta accompagnata dall'ancella...fol. 46 verso e fol. 47 recto - Caccia al cinghiale e caccia al toro (su due pagine).

BB_1961_title_recto: Cinque piccoli schizzi di nudi seduti (quello all'estrema sinistra simile ad Abia dormiente nella lunetta di "Roboam e Abia") iscritto "di quindici di sectebre" nell'angolo superiore sinistro dalla mano di Michelangelo
BB_1961_title_verso: Otto piccoli nudi, tre dei quali sono varianti di un uomo seduto frontalmente che legge un libro
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian
BB_1938_title_recto: Four leaves from a small sketch-book now joined together as a single sheet, containing on front and back sketches for the Ceiling of the Sixtine Chapel. For a complete description of these leaflets I refer the reader to Robinson's catalogue
BB_1938_text_recto: These sketches positively are not by Michelangelo, but by some pupil who naturally took up all his master's mannerisms and tricks of shorthand. It is conceivable that some of these scrawls were made after Michelangelo's own sketches, which would of course have been accessible to the pupil. But there is no need of this hypothesis. The author may have entered Michelangelo's service just when the Ceiling was finished, and, after attaining to a certain mastery, have been put for practice in rapid drawing to make these hasty notes after the frescoes. The sketchbook from which these leaflets come must have been given to his apprentice by Michelangelo himself, for on one leaf we find written in his hand "quindici di settembre," and on another (on of the leaflets under my 1703) "dagli bere." It would be of some interest to know who was this apprentice, and I venture to say that a clue to his identity is offered in the two lines of writing on the leaflet with God the Father. In them the words Silvio and Magliano occur. The character of the hand does not seem to me Michelangelo's, but betrays his influence, and as for the phrases, they seem to me just the kind that a person would write listlessly and almost unconsciously in that unimaginative mood when nothing occurs to one but one's own name. Now, as it happens, Silvio Falconi da Magliano is not only a real name, but the name of a pupil of Michelangelo's. Prof. Frey (Briefe, pp. 21, 84) has published two of his letters to his master, wherein it appears that in August, 1514, he was left in Rome as foreman of the atelier, and that in 1517 he was already painting on his own account, not in Rome, however, where he could find no employment, but at Magliano. It thus would seem that in him no more than in his direct successor Urbano, or in Mini, Urbino or any other of his men-of-all-work, did Michelangelo happen upon a man of talent. I would assume, then, that these sketches are by the hand which listlessly scrawled down the name, and that the name was the person's own, and thus Silvio Falconi's. Until disproved I will hold that this is a hold that this is a good working hypothesis.
Cataloguer's Comments: In BB_1961 we find an introduction for the others 1702-1703 drawings: Otto pagine di un taccuino quadrato, riunite nel 1836 in due pagine di cm 27.5 x 27 (onde i due numeri di Robinson e di Berenson), ma ridivise e montate separatamente nel 1953, contenenti schizzi di figure simili a quelle sulla volta della Cappella Sistina.

BB_1961_title_recto: Piccola figura corrispondente a Obed nella lunetta di "Salmon-Boaz-Obed", altra piccola figura corrispondente alla figura a sinistra nella lunetta di Aminabad su scala maggiore, mano destra e braccio sinistro
BB_1961_title_verso: Nell'angolo superiore destro figura simile alla Sibilla Persica; due studi su scala diversa simili alla figura a destra nella lunetta di "Roboam e Abia"; altre tre figurette
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as 1938, in Italian

BB_1961_title_recto: Tre varianti dell'Eterno nella "Separazione della luce dalle tenebre" e cinque figurette di cui due corrispondenti alla donna a destra nella lunetta di "Jesse-David-Salomone" iscritto in alto "M A roma Siluio in roma falconi damagliano / siluio di messere... Damagliano in roma."
BB_1961_title_verso: Studio per l'uomo a sinistra nella lunetta distrutta di "Phares-Esrom-Aram" (a carboncino); quattro figurette forse per il Giona e tre deboli schizzi nell'angolo superiore sinistro forse per l'Eterno che separa la luce dalle tenebre (a penna).

BB_1961_title_recto: Vecchio mendicante seminudo con cane, ambedue in profilo a destra
BB_1961_title_verso: Cinque figurette, di cui una seduta a leggere un libro e un'altra simile alla donna col bambino in grembo nella lunetta di "Ezechias-Manasse-Aman"
BB_1961_text_recto: Same as BB 1702 and 1703 note 1938, in Italian
BB_1938_title_recto: Four more leaves from same sketch-book containing studies after the Sixtine Ceiling. For a full description I again refer to Robinson
BB_1938_text_recto: For a full description I again refer to Robinson [and to Frey, Text, pp. 71-74]. These sketches, if my hypothesis be correct, are also by Silvio Falconi. Note: One of them calls for particular mention. I have hiterto failed to observe that the leaflet reproduced by Frey on the upper right of his pl. 153 representing an old pilgrim hobbling along bent double over his staff with his dog ambling just in front of him corresponds with the reverse of the portrait medal of Michelangelo made by Leone Leoni in 1561 not in detail but in design. It is not likely that Leoni was acquainted with this jotting. He probably followed a drawing from Michelangelo's own hand. Indeed Vasari says as much. The odd thing is that the pilgrim in our scrawl looks much  more like Michelangelo aged 85 than he does in the medal, where of course Leoni translated  him into his own forms. What are we to infer? That this sketch is the copy of a drawing from his earlier years that Michelangelo had kept for 40 years and then gave to Leoni?
Cataloguer's Comments: In BB_1961 we find an introduction for the others 1702-1703 drawings: Otto pagine di un taccuino quadrato, riunite nel 1836 in due pagine di cm 27.5 x 27 (onde i due numeri di Robinson e di Berenson), ma ridivise e montate separatamente nel 1953, contenenti schizzi di figure simili a quelle sulla volta della Cappella Sistina. The BB_1961_Text is transcripted in BB 1703d.

BB_1961_title_recto: Quarantuno schizzi dal vero di alberi e di paesi
Taccuino contenente venti fogli con schizzi di figure intere, di teste, di braccia, di piedi e di particolari architettonici
BB_1938_title_recto: Sketch-book containing twenty leaves with various drawings of entire figures, heads, hands, feet, and details of architecture
BB_1938_text_recto: They seem to have been produced in the studio of Benozzo. If found separated from the contaminating vicinity of inferior work, one might be tempted, but should resist the temptation, to give the three following (Foll. 5, 6.B, 8.B) to the master himself. None of the others come quite so close to Benozzo.

BB_1961_title_recto: Sono pagine dallo stesso libro di appunti dei precedenti, e contengono vari studi, alcuni a penna, altri a punta di pennello e acquerello di bistro, di motivi architettonici e decorativi
BB_1938_title_recto: Are leaves out of the same sketch-book as the last few, and contain various studies, some in pen and ink, others in bistre and wash, of architectural and decorative motives
Cataloguer's Question: See Inventory number and Editions' number.

BB_1961_title_recto: Testa di giovane ricciuto, dalla bocca dolce; braccio destro che tiene un sasso nella mano e mano sinistra
BB_1961_title_verso: San Rocco, fra Santa Caterina e Sant'Antonio Abate.
BB_1961_text_recto: Per gli altri disegni montati insieme a questo dal Vasari sul recto del foglio, vedi BB nn. 1276, 1276 A, 1276 B.
BB_1961_text_verso:
Sembra uno studio per il trittico con i medesimi Santi nella Chiesa di San Felice
a Firenze, dipinto nella bottega del Botticelli. √à cosi vicino al Garbo nella sua
maniera botticelliana da rendere probabile che sia di lui. Per l'altro disegno montato
insieme vedi BB n. 1275.
BB_1938_title_recto:
Head of curly haired youth with sweet looking mouth and
characteristic expression. Also an arm with stone in hand.
BB_1938_title_verso:
St. Roch between St. Catherine and Anthony Abbot. Highly coloured.
St. Roch in a separate panel. All within a frame drawn in bistre.
BB_1938_text_verso:
Probably done in
preparation for the triptych in S. Felice at Florence painted in Botticelli's studio. So close to Garbo in his  Botticellian manner as to make it probable that it is by him. For
other drawings framed in with these by Vasari on both recto and verso see my 1275,
1276, 1276A, and 1276B.
BB_1903_title_recto: Head of curly-haired Youth. Sweet look and mouth. Characteristic expression. Also an arm with stone in hand.
Cataloguer's Question: Only verso was former 571...how can I note it?
